snippet: The face of the campaign for same-sex marriage in Maine isn't one you'd expect.
abstract: The face of the campaign for same-sex marriage in Maine isn't one you'd expect.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

snippet: In the South of Market area of San Francisco, a new generation of tech dreamers is moving into housing previously unseen: high-rise condos.

headline.main: In San Francisco, High-Rises by the Bay

snippet: Just four months after a much-hyped introduction, the video chat company has laid off employees and is tweaking its features.
abstract: Airtime, video chat site created by Napster veterans Sean Parker and Shawn Fanning, has lost important employees and laid off others only four months after its much-hyped introduction; story reflects the challenges for any start-up, regardless of pedigree, in winning over users when so many other sites, apps and services are vying for their attention.

headline.main: Airtime, a Pedigreed Start-Up, Is Tested

snippet: The Court of Appeal in Britain backed a judgment that the Samsung Galaxy tablet computer was “not as cool” as the Apple iPad, and therefore did not infringe on Apple’s rights.
abstract: Court of Appeal in Britain backs a judgment that the Samsung Galaxy tablet computer is 'not as cool' as the Apple iPad, and therefore does not infringe on Apple’s rights.

headline.main: Apple Loses Copyright Appeal Against Samsung in Britain
headline.print_headline: Apple Loses Copyright Appeal Against Samsung in Britain

snippet: Once we thought a rising tide would lift all boats. Now some economists think a few boats need a push, before the economy can really expand.
abstract: Once we thought a rising tide would lift all boats. Now some economists think a few boats need a push, before the economy can really expand.

headline.main: Shrink Inequality to Grow the Economy?

snippet: A 2008 PBS “Frontline” video report on militants in Pakistan’s Swat Valley included rare footage of Maulana Fazlullah, a leader of the Pakistani Taliban who reportedly ordered the attack on 15-year-old Malala Yousafzai.
abstract: A 2008 PBS “Frontline” video report on militants in Pakistan’s Swat Valley included rare footage of Maulana Fazlullah, a leader of the Pakistani Taliban who reportedly ordered the attack on 15-year-old Malala Yousafzai.

headline.main: Rare Video of Pakistani Taliban's 'Radio Mullah,' Blamed for Attack on Schoolgirl

snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday's selection includes a 25,000-person consulting firm switching to iPhones and Android phones from BlackBerrys, a look at Silicon Va...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday's selection includes a 25,000-person consulting firm switching to iPhones and Android phones from BlackBerrys, a look at Silicon Valley housing values and a gallery of computers as portrayed in movies (one even uses punch cards).

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Hollywood's Silliest Computers, and Facebook Changes Dating

snippet: Google’s quarterly results, released early by mistake, reflected losses at Motorola Mobility and plummeting prices for clicks on ads.
abstract: Google shares plummet by more than 9 percent after the company releases a disappointing earnings report, spurring Nasdaq to halt trading in its shares in the early afternoon; company reported third-quarter net income of $2.18 billion, down from $2.73 billion a year ago, reflecting a reduction in the price advertisers pay per click on ads.

headline.main: Shares Fall Sharply as Google Earnings Are Released Early
headline.print_headline: Google Shares Fall on Disappointing Earnings

snippet: Both Windows and Mac OS X can provide a hint for the computer's password.
abstract: Both Windows and Mac OS X can provide a hint for the computer's password.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Set Your Own Password Reminder

snippet: In his first public appearance since the company said he lost his voice for undisclosed health reasons, Larry Page, Google's chief executive, answered questions about antitrust and privacy investigations, Google Maps on the iPhone and Google's com...
abstract: In his first public appearance since the company said he lost his voice for undisclosed health reasons, Larry Page, Google's chief executive, answered questions about antitrust and privacy investigations, Google Maps on the iPhone and Google's company culture.

headline.main: Larry Page on Regulation, Maps and Google's Social Mission
